why are you asking me to even build this project and i might be even asking the architects

and then finally what and when it comes to the what i'm not a big fan of seeing

why we've got a hack in place i don't care what it's doing or what or what has been

of headaches and bugs down the track so
so if we've now really discovered our why and we've really started to

a car design firm and as someone who doesn't have any

so that's at a higher level of how i like to tackle my domain driven design
and if we've covered off the y we've really focused down on that why
we've really narrowed down and identified how we're going to build that product i
guess now's a great time to start looking at what we're actually going to build
and for that i'm sure a lot of people can are familiar with the term of the mvp
the minimum viable product the mvp as introduced uh in the lean startup by
eric ruriz is basically the simplest experiment we can run
to gain validated learning and what that means is that
we might have an assumption about customer needs and customer demands but it's just an
assumption let's hypothesize let's write an experiment and let's
identify ways that we can actually test out these assumptions these hypotheses and see
exactly and really start to get validation as to whether or not these
are correct we can adapt and we can evolve and change our product as we run more experiments
so i've got this image here that's made the rounds around the internet by henry nyberg
which shows two different ways people might consider tackling an mvp and he says the top way is the
wrong way the bottom way is the right way so the differences i find between the two
is obviously in the top one we don't get a usable product until the very end of our release cycle
and the second one we actually do get a a deliverable product at each point that
we can put in front of the customer and we can start to start to get them to use it and get
their feedback on them in the first one we can identify
customers needs and demands based on the feature that we're currently working on
but in the second one we're going to get that feedback across the product space as a whole
and finally one of the big differences i find is in the bottom one or in the top one
there's a good chance that the previous features that we've worked on we're going to carry those through and we're going to move those through the
pipeline and they're going to be available within our finished product whereas the second one
there's a good chance that the work that we're working on today is going to get thrown out over the next
couple of days or the next iteration and we're going to start again we're going to use those learnings but the actual products that we're building
we're going to throw them out and start again now this diagram has been debated
there's a lot of debates online about it and i know in my past in my history i
always thought that this seemed a bit backwards and i'd much rather i'd be more happier if it was the other
way around but what i've come to realize is that i think that's because of my bias
is coming from the an enterprise developer from the enterprise space
so if we think back to the purpose of me that bottom purpose of identifying customer needs identifying

but from an enterprise point of view if i'm working on a project there's a good chance that the business

or external defined they know there's a demand for it we're generally going to be
replacing a legacy system or building or digitizing a a process and optimizing processes
and what i found was that nine times out of ten i'm not really

what i find that's missing here is context we really need to identify why

that's a platform based mbp and what i feel here is well if i'm
doing a platform-based mvp i can start to start on one side at the
less scalable side so it might be a bit more expensive and if we take the analogy of the car factory again
i might start building a very expensive custom bespoke car very low numbers but quite expensive
and what i'm doing here is proving that we can build cars i'm proving that my

so from my point of view
what does a platform-based mvp look like first up i really want to prove my
platform i want to prove that everything that we're working on is actually going to do what i wanted to do
so what that means for me is one of the first things i like to do is implement what i consider boilerplate or what a lot of
people might consider boilerplate stuff working on your ci cd pipeline getting your authentication and
your logging and your tracing done all in place because getting it done at the beginning
when i've got an empty clean slate is going to be a lot easier than it will be to get it done
down the track if i've got a if if i wait several months or years to
actually start to implement these things or several features down the track to implement my authentication of my blogging
i've got a lot of legacy code that i actually need to start getting these in place but i don't have my cicd
pipelines up and running implementing them down the track is going to be a lot harder than
implementing them now and evolving them as my needs change
likewise i really want to test out my deployments i want to ensure that that i can deploy
my my micro services over to microsoft business environment i want to ensure that i can deploy these
services independently make sure that they're not tightly coupled make sure that i can
have one service independently developed updating their versions changing their
model building things up one service without the other i don't want to see to if we don't test
these deployments early on when i've got a half a dozen to a dozen or more microsurface
services in play it's going to be a lot harder to actually get these things down it's going to be so much easier to do it
at day one we can start to test out our blue green deployments we can test our failure scenarios let's
let's really stress test all these things early on because like i could keep saying if we
leave it down the track it's just going to be so much more difficult to actually get through and on that
we're going to start to really test out our microservices
well we're going to test out our architecture i should say so if we're going a monolith or microservices
